training_organizations.name: New York OCFS Bureau of Training
training_organizations.description: The New York State Office of Children & Family Services has a Bureau of Training responsible for child welfare workforce development. It oversees the training of CPS staff in New York’s state-supervised, county-run system by setting curriculum and standards. Through contracts with SUNY and CUNY institutions, the bureau ensures that caseworkers and supervisors across all counties receive consistent core training and required annual education to maintain their skills.

training_organizations.name: SUNY Albany Professional Development Program (PDP)
training_organizations.description: A university-based program that serves as a major training contractor for New York’s child welfare system. PDP develops and delivers a wide array of child welfare trainings on behalf of OCFS, including new caseworker core training, supervisory training, and specialized courses (such as preventive services, adoption casework, and juvenile justice crossover youth). Its trainers travel statewide to equip county CPS staff with up-to-date knowledge.

training_organizations.name: Welfare Research, Inc. (WRI)
training_organizations.description: A nonprofit organization in New York that provides training, technical assistance, and research for child welfare initiatives under contract with OCFS. WRI has assisted with implementing new practice models and data analysis. For example, WRI staff help train child welfare professionals on new policies or pilot programs, and they offer consulting expertise to counties in improving outcomes, acting as an external support arm for the state.

training_organizations.name: New York City ACS Workforce Institute
training_organizations.description: A partnership between NYC’s Administration for Children’s Services and CUNY that delivers training to child welfare and juvenile justice staff in the city. The Workforce Institute provides ongoing professional development to ACS caseworkers and supervisors (post-hire) on topics like motivational interviewing, trauma-informed care, and supervisory coaching. This is in addition to the pre-service training ACS staff receive, and is aimed at continually elevating practice quality in NYC’s large child welfare system.

training_organizations.name: The New York Foundling
training_organizations.description: A historic nonprofit organization in New York City that contracts with ACS to provide a range of child welfare services. The New York Foundling manages foster care cases (receiving referrals from ACS to place children in foster homes it oversees), runs preventive services programs to support families and avoid foster care, and operates residential programs for youth. As one of many provider agencies in NYC’s network, it carries out day-to-day case management for a portion of the city’s children in foster care under ACS oversight.

policies.TribalFoster: Yes, Tribes within state provide foster care
policies.InvestQual_SW: Yes, recommended or preferred, but not required
policies.ReportAnonymous: General public (not mandated reporters) can remain anonymous
policies.ScreenerQual_SW: Yes, recommended or preferred, but not required
policies.Def_OtherSpecify: Unreasonably inflicting or allowing to be inflicted harm by any other acts of a similarly serious nature requiring the aid of the court
policies.FatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.Def_Subtype_Abuse: Abuse includes physical abuse, emotional maltreatment, sexual abuse, female genital mutilation, and permitting, encouraging, or allowing child sex trafficking. Depending upon acts, physical abuse, excessive corporal punishment, sexual abuse, shaken baby syndrome, and abusive head trauma, could constitute child abuse
policies.AlternativeResponse: Yes--implemented in specific counties or regions
policies.Def_Subtype_Neglect: Neglect includes inadequate food, inadequate clothing, inadequate shelter, educational neglect, medical neglect, injurious environment, illegally providing controlled substance to a child, child present within structure where methamphetamine is being created, parent responsibilities (harm due to inadequate supervision, failure to meet parent or caretaker responsibilities), failure to protect, excessive corporal punishment, drug or alcohol misuse, and abandonment. Depending upon acts, physical abuse, excessive corporal punishment, sexual abuse, misuse of drugs or alcohol, misuse of drugs or alcohol, shaken baby syndrome, and abusive head trauma could constitute child neglect
policies.EquityStaff_Specify: Office of Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Accessibility (ODEIA)
policies.Exempt_OtherSpecify: Circumcision, excision or infibulation is not a violation if it is necessary to the health of the person on whom it is performed or done on a person in labor or who has just given birth and is performed for medical purposes connected with that labor
policies.NearFatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews can be conducted but are not required
policies.Reporter_OtherSpecify: Christian Science practitioner; Any other child care or foster care worker; Any person credentialed by New York State Office of Addiction Services and Supports
policies.InvestReq_OtherSpecify: Determination of the nature, extent and cause of any condition enumerated in report and any other condition that may constitute abuse or maltreatment; Determination of the name, age and condition of the children in the home; Seeing to the safety of the child or children; After seeing to the safety of the child or children, notification in writing to the subjects of the report and other persons named in the report of the existence of the report and of their respective rights (no later than 7 days after receipt of the report); Obtaining information from reporting sources and other collateral sources which may have information relevant to the allegations in the report and to the safety of the children; Request copies of materials in the case records of other districts that are not part of the CONNECTIONS (CONNX) record (e.g., medical reports, schools, police, social service and other agencies, relatives, neighbors)
policies.ScreenReq_OtherSpecify: When a CPS using Family Assessment Response (FAR) receives a new report, staff confirm the report is within the LDSS's jurisdiction and uses the LDSS screening protocol to determine whether the report is eligible for the FAR track and decide on investigation or FAR track; In certain cases, LDSS also informs law enforcement or a supervisor offers the reporter a consultation
policies.ReportInfo_OtherSpecify: Any other information which the commissioner of the Office of Children and Family Services (OCFS) may, by regulation, require
policies.ScreenInfo_OtherSpecify: 8 elements are needed to register a report of suspected child abuse/maltreatment in New York State: (1) Reasonable cause to suspect that a (2) minor child (less than eighteen years old) has been (3) impaired/harmed or is in (4) imminent danger of impairment/risk of harm because of the failure of a (5) parent or person legally responsible for the child to exercise a (6) minimum degree of care (7) within the jurisdiction in New York State based on residence of child and/or alleged subject and where the alleged maltreatment took place (8) with sufficient demographic information to locate the alleged subject and so Child Protective Services can initiate an investigation
policies.DefHarm_VaryByTypeSpecify: For sexual abuse and abandonment, there is not a requirement to specify harm. It is assumed in the finding
policies.DefPerp_VaryByTypeSpecify: Only a parent or other person legally responsible for a child's care can abandon a child
policies.InvestQual_TrainingSpecify: Basic approved training program within three months of employment and annual in-service training beginning in the second year of employment
policies.AltResp_Inelig_OtherSpecify: Failure to thrive; Abandonment; Severe or repeated abuse; Sexual exploitation; Any allegations of abuse
policies.AntiDiscrim_Who_SomeSpecify: Children and youth in foster care; Foster parents, kinship caretakers, and other out-of-home placement caregivers
policies.AntiDiscrim_Who_VarySpecify: Children and youth in foster care, foster parents, kinship, and other out-of-home placement caregivers are covered for gender identity or expression, sexual orientation, and marital status; All children, youth, and families engaged in the child welfare system are covered for the following characteristics: age, race, disability, religion, national origin, marital status, and sex
policies.AltResp_Process_OtherSpecify: At intake a report is flagged as eligible for differential response if certain criteria are met. However, local departments of social services must use their own procedures and criteria to make a final assignment of the report to differential response.
policies.CaseManagerQual_OtherSpecify: New York State does not have qualification standards. Such standards may be set at the county level by the local departments of social services. Each CPS must maintain a sufficient level of staff who are sufficiently qualified and trained, as specified by OCFS, to perform duties. It is preferable that CPS workers have an educational background or experience in social work or a related field and be skillful and experienced in working with children and families.
policies.InvestQual_ExperienceSpecify: 2 years of experience of relevant child welfare services experience for CPS supervisors; Unspecified relevant human services experience for non-supervisory workers, depending on degree
policies.ReporterPenalty_OtherSpecify: Christian Science practitioner; Any other child care or foster care worker; Any person credentialed by New York State Office of Addiction Services and Supports
policies.ScreenReq_OtherCases_Specify: LDSS contacts law enforcement when there is an allegation of maltreatment resulting in physical harm, when the report is made by a mandated reporter and there have been two other indicated or pending reports made within the last six months that involve the same child, sibling, or other children in the household, or the subject of the report); If the report is going to be screened out (does not meet criteria to be registered), a SCR supervisor offers the reporter a consultation
policies.DefMal_Harm_VaryByTypeSpecify: Definition of maltreatment both include harm, but they vary by the standard or level of harm; Definition for child abuse includes a standard of 'substantial risk' of death, serious or protracted disfigurement or protracted impairment of physical or emotional health or protracted loss or impairment of any bodily organ; Definition for child neglect includes a standard that the child is in 'imminent danger' of harm
policies.FatalitiesDefine_OtherSpecify: Death of a child for whom any local department of social services or a voluntary authorized agency has an open child protective or preventive services case
policies.ReporterTraining_OtherSpecify: Christian Science practitioner; Any other child care or foster care worker; Any person credentialed by New York State Office of Addiction Services and Supports
policies.InvestReq_MedEvalCases_Specify: CPS units evaluate whether a medical exam is needed when a child named in a report has been physically abused or neglected, failed to thrive, lacks necessary medical care, where an examination is crucial for completing an investigation, or where the child requires immediate treatment
policies.ScreenerQual_ExperienceSpecify: 2 years of experience in the direct provision of child welfare programs with an associate's degree; 4 years of experience in the direct provision of child welfare programs
policies.AltResp_EligibilityMaltreatment: Only certain types of maltreatment are eligible
policies.ExtFosterCare_Reentry_OtherSpec: No reasonable alternative to foster care; A compelling reason for such former foster care youth to return to foster care; Re-entry motion filed within 24 months from the date of first final discharge that occurred on or after the youth's 18th birthday; Youth is participating in workforce development/training program
policies.InvestReq_PerpCrimCases_Specify: CPS units may apply to be able to obtain criminal history information for the perpetrator/other adults in the home on a report
policies.InvestReq_ReporterCases_Specify: Reports that were not made anonymously
policies.AltResp_EligibilityRiskOtherSpec: Determination that each child named in the CPS report or known to be living in the household is safe in the home. In operative terms, this means that there is a safety decision of "1" or "2" in the initial safety assessment.
policies.AltResp_Eligibility_OtherSpecify: The local department of social services (LDSS) is responsible for establishing protocol that specifies the types of allegations of maltreatment and situations that the CPS will or will not consider for potential assignment to FAR. The LDSS may establish more restrictive standards for the categories of reports it will accept for FAR. Must be compliant with state and local screening criteria including: (1) satisfactory record review, (2) no open CPS investigation, and (3) agreement by parents, guardians, or persons legally responsible for child. Some categories of New York defined maltreatment/neglect are eligible. The following categories are potentially eligible: (1) inadequate guardianship, (2) lack of supervision, (3) lack of food, clothing, shelter, (4) medical neglect, (5) educational neglect, (6) lacerations, bruises, welts, (7) excessive corporal punishment that does not rise to the level of abuse, (8) failure to provide minimum level of care for children due to misuse of alcohol or drugs.
policies.AlternativeResp_VaryLocalSpecify: Any social services district may, upon the authorization of the Office of Children and Family Services, establish a program that implements differential responses to reports of child abuse and maltreatment
